Award.AwardTitle: Identifying the Rules Governing Tripeptide Gelation in Aqueous Solution.
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical abstract

The discovery and characterization of biodegradable gels are important to many biomaterial applications. Low molecular weight peptides attracted increasing interest as gel forming compounds due to their low synthesis costs and the ease by which their reactive sites can be modified. Peptides are known to self-assemble into supramolecular structures, such as ribbons, nanotubes, and monolayers, which are predominantly composed of sheet-like structures. Several diseases are linked to the self-assembly of peptides/proteins including Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's disease and Huntington's disease. Overall very little is understood regarding the self-assembly of peptides/proteins into fibrils. With respect to biotechnology, the self-assembly process has very positive aspects. It allows the generation of biocompatible material with incorporated biological function. Their biomedical and biotechnological relevance for developing suitable protocols for drug delivery, microfluidics, and tissue engineering/repair, is well established. This project will focus on elucidating specific interactions between peptides that lead to self-assembly and bulk gelation. Phase diagrams will be constructed to identify material constraints and identify potential applications for series of peptides. The results are expected to bring significant insight into designing new peptides with tailored or controlled aggregation kinetics and gelation properties for a broad range of applications. The project outcomes will have significant impact in understanding and interpreting the role of peptides and their sequence in disease manifestation. Lastly, the project will result in the training of graduate and undergraduate students in the fields of Chemistry, Chemical Engineering, and Physics.

Technical abstract

This research project is motivated by the discovery of the unexpected gelation of cationic glycylalanylglycine (GAG) in ethanol/water and glycylhistidylglycine (GHG) in water at neutral pH. The planned experiments and computations are aimed at a thorough assessment of the molecular mechanisms and microscopic and macroscopic properties of gels formed by the above unblocked GxG peptides. We will focus initially on five tripeptides: GAG, GHG, GVG, GDG and GFG and their respective blocked derivatives. Experimental investigations will determine the effect of environment (solvent composition, pH, temperature, peptide concentration) on peptide conformation and interaction energies. Rheology will be used to determine the strength, compliance, and recovery of volume spanning networks. Circular dichroism (CD), IR, vibrational spectroscopy, and rheology will be used to construct phase diagrams with regard to temperature, peptide concentration, pH and the mole fraction of co-solvents. The phase diagrams will also be analyzed in the context of current theories of gelation to determine interaction energies. Finally, investigations will focus on exploring the different steps of the tripeptide gelation process: from the onset of tripeptide aggregation to the formation of large scale fibrils. Some key questions that will be answered are how the peptides are integrated into a sample spanning network and what type of structure and conformation do the peptides make inside fibrils. A strong emphasis will be placed on characterizing the kinetics of gelation and the dependence of kinetic rates on external stimuli. Furthermore, we will determine the local conformation of peptides in the crystalline fibrils by combining vibrational spectroscopy data with molecular dynamics and density functional calculations. The unique comparison and analysis of simultaneous rheological, computational and spectroscopic data will unfold the complexities of peptide aggregation, fibrillization, and ultimately network formation from the molecular to macroscopic scale. The proposed research is clearly at the interface between physics, chemistry and biology. The project would provide funding for graduate students and one undergraduate student. Graduate and undergraduate students will be trained on a variety of instruments and learn how to combine rather different data sets into a common picture describing the investigated systems. Undergraduate research will be become part of the student's Co-op experience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Identifying the Rules Governing Tripeptide Gelation in Aqueous Solution.

 

Intelectual Merits

The sponsored research was aimed at exploring the capability of short tripeptides to self-assemble and gel either in water or in water/alcohol mixtures. The peptides are composed of two glycines and a guest amino acid residue that we varied among a selected set of 20 natural amino acids. We found that peptides with alanine as guest residue can form strong gels in water/ethanol mixtures. Peptides with aromatic guest residues were found to self-assemble and gel in water. Histidine containing tripeptides gel if the pH of the solution is lowered from an acidic value to 6.0 and higher. Tripeptides with phenylalanine as guest residue form gels when they are subjected to a heating (80 0C) - cooling cycle. The use of tyrosine and tryptophan as guest residues allows for gelation after heating/cooling and by exposing the samples to acidic pH. All the investigated tripeptide gels have in common that their strength is exceptional high compared with gels formed with other short peptides reported in the literature. Generally, microscopy revealed that the obtained gels are underlied by a sample spanning network of very large fibrils which are even detectable by visual inspection, which explains their exceptional strengths. Generally, fibrils formed by even short peptides are formed by self-assembly of β-sheets. However, spectroscopic evidence and crystal structures obtained from x-ray-diffraction data strongly suggest that this is not the case for the fibrils formed by the investigated peptides. Thermal annealing experiments for alanine and phenylalanine containing tripeptides show that the respective gel phases are not fully reversible which indicates that the gel phase is metastable, most likely with a very long lifetime. For any biomedical application it is of great importance that the gel strength can be adjusted in order to meet specific needs. We found that this is the case for all the investigated tripeptide gels. The rather peculiar concentrations dependence of the gel strengths are particularly helpful in this regard. In order to fully characterize the phases leading to fibril and gel formation in quantitative terms we combined several techniques which are not all common in material science research. We used vibrational spectroscopy to characterize the structure and the chirality of the fibrils and to monitor the kinetics of sheet formations, UV-circular dichroism spectroscopy to probe spectroscopy to probe the kinetics of fibrilization, rheology to determine the gel strength and the kinetics of gel formation and x-ray diffraction to gain additional structural information about the gel phase. Thus far collected data suggest that the peculiar structural properties of the obtained gel phases are due to the synergy between different types of non-covalent interpeptide interactions. In this context non-traditional hydrogen bonding involving ned groups and side chains seem to play an important role. 

 

Broader impact

Scientifically, the obtained results on tripeptides have identified a new class of gelators with exceptional properties. There is hope that the very large strength of some gels make the material suitable for tissue repair. We are currently investigating the usability of the gels for the storage and delivery of hydrophobic drugs. We expect that some our results, particularly the one obtained with phenylalanine containing peptides, are sufficient for filling a patent application. Regarding human resources the research for the project provided a comprehensive training for a significant number of graduate and undergraduate students. Over time a significant number of undergraduate. students (4) got involved in project related research. One of them was supported by an REU-supplement grant. The success of these undergraduate projects is reflected by five authorships on peer-reviewed papers. The REU-supported students published two papers as first author. Overall, the project educated two female and one male graduate student and three female and one male undergraduate student.
